stem: The nurse is participating in a cultural humility workshop. Match each term with its correct definition to ensure inclusive care.

columns.text: An internal, deeply held sense of being male, female, or another gender.
Individuals whose gender identity differs from the sex assigned at birth.
Individuals whose gender identity aligns with the sex assigned at birth.
A person who identifies as neither entirely male nor entirely female.

rationale.correct: Accurate terminology is the foundation of health equity for LGBTQ+ clients. (r1) Cisgender = Alignment of identity and birth sex. (r2) Non-binary = Identity outside the male/female binary. (r3) Transgender = Identity that differs from birth sex. (r4) Gender identity is the internal perception of self.
rationale.incorrect: Sexual orientation (who you love) is distinct from gender identity (who you are).
clinicalPearls: The single most important step in establishing trust with a transgender client is using their correct pronouns and chosen name.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that a person can be transgender (identity) and also be gay, straight, or bisexual (orientation). They are separate clinical categories.

mnemonic.title: I-A-B-O
mnemonic.expansion: Identity (Who I am), Aligns (Cis), Beyond binary (Non-binary), Opposite/Across (Trans).

reviewUnits.heading: Gender-Inclusive Care
reviewUnits.body: Nurses have an ethical duty to provide care that respects the patient's identity. Clinical documentation and triage should use standardized, inclusive terminology to ensure safety and equity.
